metaData.descriptionCS: On Receptive Vocabulary, the examinee points to the picture that best illustrates the meaning of each word he or she hears. On Oral Discourse Comprehension, the examinee listens to sentences and passages and orally responds to comprehension questions.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 1. Empty
questions.incorrectInstructionsHTML:
Incorrect response:

Point to the correct picture and say, This picture shows empty because this box has no more pizza in it. It is empty. None of the other pictures show an empty box. Let’s try again. Point to the picture that shows empty. Encourage the examinee to provide the correct response, and then proceed to Item 2 by saying, Let’s try some more.
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Empty. Touch the picture that shows empty.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 2. Jar
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
(Touch) jar.

Administration directions in parentheses are optional when the examinee has demonstrated sufficient task comprehension. Older or more mature examinees may be encouraged to provide the letter that corresponds to the picture, rather than touching.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 3. Pair
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) pair.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 4. Doze
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) doze.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 5. Pen
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) pen.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 6. Festive
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) festive.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 7. Exhausted
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) exhausted.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 8. Identical
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) identical.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 9. Canine
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) canine.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 10. Astounded
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) astounded.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 11. Currency
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) currency.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 12. Descending
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) descending.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 13. Ravine
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) ravine.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 14. Tethered
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) tethered.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 15. Pinnacle
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) pinnacle.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 16. Opaque
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) opaque.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 17. Solitary
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) solitary.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 18. Bucolic
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) bucolic.

questions.title: Receptive Vocabulary Item 19. Ponderous
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Touch) ponderous.

consecutiveZerosDiscontinueRule.description: This subtest discontinues after 4 consecutive scores of 0 points.

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 1
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Where does the bird sing?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 2
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Who is running?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 3
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, When was it raining?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 4
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What do the people want to plant?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 5
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What did Lee see first?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 6
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What day is Sally visiting Grandma?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 7
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What does Jackie have to do before she goes to the animal shelter?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 8
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Why did Amy want to climb the tree?

answers.text: Her kitten is in the tree

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 9
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What reason did Amy's grandfather give for her not climbing the tree?

answers.text: (He said) her kitten will come down when she's ready

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 10
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What do you get free?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 11
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Name two of the animals shown on the mugs.

answers.popoverText: Say, Tell me another animal shown on mugs.

1.conditionalText: Names at least two of the following:

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 12
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which animal did Richard see last?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 13
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Which sport does Julie most like to watch on television?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 14
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How many cutouts do you need to send in to get a free pass?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 15
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, After you send in the cutouts, what is the longest time you will have to wait for the free pass?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 16
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What is the first event Troy's family goes to on the Fourth of July?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 17
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Name two advantages given for the proposed building.

answers.text: Comparative terms not used (e.g., the student says, "Good parking")
answers.popoverText: Say, Name two advantages that make the proposed building better than the current one.

answers.text: More efficient heating and cooling system

1.conditionalText: Names at least two of the following, using the comparative terms listed:

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 18
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What office is Gerald running for?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 19
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, To Gerald, what is the most important reason for running for office?

answers.text: He wants to be in politics (in the future)

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 20
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What advantage does walking have over running?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 21
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Besides health, what is one reason given in support of walking?

answers.text: Examinee gives a health related reason
Can be done at any time of day
Can be done in almost any place

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 22
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What is the first book in the series about?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 23
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, How much do you have to spend before you get the free item?

answers.text: Seven ninety-five / Seven dollars and ninety-five cents

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 24
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, In what direction would Ms. Franklin be traveling for most of the train trip that she wants to win?

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 25
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, By how much did unemployment change in one month, and in what direction?

answers.popoverText: Say, And by how much did unemployment change in one month?
Say, And in what direction did unemployment change in one month?

answers.text: Decreased by three-quarters of one percent

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 26
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, What effect did students have on unemployment in one month?

answers.text: Their return to school created job opportunities / made more jobs available

questions.title: Oral Discourse Comprehension Item 27
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, In 1984, how many robots were produced in the United States?

consecutiveZerosDiscontinueRule.description: This subtest discontinues after 4 consecutive scores of 0 points.
